Apparently I dont know how to add people to a channel in slack.   I've just been in here posting to myself, even though I know I invited <@U026PHQ3J> and <@U026PT0D7>
<@U026PT0D7|spilliams> has joined the channel
so really you've just been in here talking to yourself
(shhhh...  don't tell, I do that a lot.)
:simple_smile:
the airlock thing is really awesome - i had been hesitant to make any kraut based on a failed attempt many years ago that resulted in a lot of mold
and was way too salty
whoa
i love watching airlocks
thats our distillation lab
at least, the boiler/PID controller end of it
are you making moonshine
moonshine is for hillbillies

I'm all about the glass+airlock.   Stoneware crocks make me nervous because I cant see what's going on inside without breaking the seal and ruining the anaerobic environment that was keeping things not-moldy
also: nah, corn mashes are notoriously slow
glass is much easier to clean than plastic too
well its the liquid thats keeping the air out, not the crock lid, right?
so as long as everything is submerged its a-ok
<@U026PHQ3J|evans> set the channel topic: Yeast Farts.
<@U0260V1BX>: correct, but if you peek in - mid process, just cause your curious - you have to break the water seal.  on the rim of your crock.  glass lets you see right in without disturbing.
I like glass mainly cause its less of a hassle to wash - you can easily see any residue you have
you also don't have to worry about how strong (pH) your cleaning chemical is
or how hot the liquids are going into it
ooh yeah
dishwasher safe!
also i like that i can warm glass in the dishwasher before i use it, so i dont murder all the yeasties
plastic is a no-no for anything but cider/beer as far as I know.
all of my ferments are all about acid, nothing good happens until you are below 3.5ph and that will leach all sorts a crap out of your plastic.
i know some people make kimchi in plastic buckets, but its probably not the best practice
<http://theoriginalsung.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/kimchi_13.jpg>
i would be worried, yeah, about leaching
wow - I know there's "food grade" plastics, but I would totally not do that.   but wow, that's a lot of kimchi!
I would like to eat most/all of that please
are those christmas/holiday storage bins from like the home depot?
the korean market by my house sells them as kimchi containers
you can order them online from "Crazy Korean Shopping"  - haha
<http://www.amazon.com/Premium-Kimchi-Sauerkraut-Fermentation-Container/dp/B00M40ANMO/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1419368890&sr=8-1&keywords=kimchi+container>

text: wow, well then, when it comes to kimchi, I'd trust a korean before I'd trust me...   but I'm sticking with glass
